title: TriFan 600: 'Forget the highway, lose the runway'
text:
TriFan 600: 'Forget the highway, lose the runway' Last updated 09:10, September 8 2015 startengine.com 
TriFan 600's central fan is tucked away beneath a sliding cover during its forward flight. 
A new "revolutionary" high-speed jet is promising to "change air travel forever" by offering quicker travel to and from more places than ever before. 
The six-seater TriFan 600 aircraft is a new design proposed by the XTI Aircraft Company, who are looking for backers on the crowdfunding website Start Engine. 
The design combines helicopter style technology that would allow the aircraft to take off and land vertically on any helipad-sized surface, while the lightweight materials allow the aircraft to enjoy the same speed and power of a private jet. 
With three advanced ducted fans, propelling the vertical lift, it is believed that TriFan 600 could reach a maximum cruise speed of 400mph in 90 seconds, before reaching its maximum cruise altitude or more than 30,000 feet (9144 metres) in 11 minutes above predominant weather. 
&amp;nbsp; 
With the tagline "Forget the highway. Lose the runway" designers are hoping the TriFan 600 would remove the need for long runways and "airport-to-airport" travel, instead travellers could be dropped door-to-door, making the aircraft the perfect form of transport for personal and business use. 
But despite the compact size of the inner-workings of the TriFan600, the designers will not be skimping on comfort. 
The "unparalleled cabin space" can also be configured to offer a "medical evacuation or air ambulatory configuration" or a cabin that offers luxury travel. 
The TriFan 600 is one of several plan aircraft designs in the works that are hoping to transform the way we travel. 
Earlier in 2015, KLM proposed their AHEAD (Advanced Hybrid Engine Aircraft Development aircraft) which would feature a blended wing that would minimise drag and reduce fuel consumption. 
Boeing's new 787 Dreamliner also displayed a almost-vertical ascent in a recent test flight before the Paris Airshow.
